Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Situation2: They notice a few pool chairs are slightly misaligned but still usable.
Story:
I stood at the edge of the pool, clipboard in hand, scanning the deck for anything out of place. As a lifeguard, I was expected to keep everything in perfect order—safety first, always. My supervisor had reminded me just this morning: “Even the small things matter. Chairs lined up, equipment checked.” I noticed a few pool chairs were slightly misaligned, not a hazard, but not up to standard either. I knew I should fix them before my shift ended.

But my mind kept drifting to my son’s hopeful face. I’d promised him a Nintendo if I got through this month without any extra expenses. He’d been counting down the days, and I could already picture his excitement. But money was tight, and every hour I spent here mattered for our budget. If I stayed late to fix the chairs, I’d miss the sale at the store, and the Nintendo would slip out of reach. My heart tugged in two directions—toward my duty as a lifeguard, and my promise as a parent. I stood frozen, clipboard pressed to my chest, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
